Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Ensure all files are UTF8 with BOM" (#256) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: GIT and many other tools work best with UTF8+BOM encoding. Most files in the repo were encoded as such, but a few weren't. This enables StyleCop to check for the encoding, and updates those files that aren't encoded correctly. Part of #197

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue ""High fidelity conversion of DOCX => HTML/CSS and HTML/CSS => DOCX."" (#257) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
The Readme file mentions that is possible to convert docx to HTML, but I didn't find any example or documentation explaining how to do it. Can anyone provide an example? I have only found using https://github.com/OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools, but due to some restrictions, I can't use this library.

Thanks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Ensure all files are UTF8 with BOM" (#256) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: GIT and many other tools work best with UTF8+BOM encoding. Most files in the repo were encoded as such, but a few weren't. This enables StyleCop to check for the encoding, and updates those files that aren't encoded correctly.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Rename generated files to end in .g.cs" (#254) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: This will allow us to run some automated tools that will skip generated files.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Turn on warnings as errors on release builds" (#255) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: It's easy to start accumulating warnings in a project. This cleans up some test code that had compilation warnings and turns on warnings as errors on release builds.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Merge Office2016 into vNext" (#243) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Merged pull request "Update xUnit to 2.3.0" (#253) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Opened pull request "Update xUnit to 2.3.0" (#253) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK

Events.RelatedBody:
As part of being able to support .NET Core, this change does the following:

- Update to the latest NuGet of DocumentFormat.OpenXml
- Convert projects to use the new csproj format (will allow .NET Standard targeting at a later point)
- Consolidates solution files into one file that has the tool, cmdlet, tests, and examples
- Adds a powershell project. This is an msbuild based project but helps organize loose files. The bin folder of this project has everything needed for a module

Initial support for #116

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "While applying background color in the html theme is applied in the wml file" (#186) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
While applying background color for the text before the image with different font the theme is applied in the wml file and assigning different font.
 <w:rFonts w:asciiTheme="minorHAnsi" w:eastAsiaTheme="minorHAnsi" w:hAnsiTheme="minorHAnsi" w:cstheme="minorBidi" />

Can anyone please give me the solution for this.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "DocumentAssembler - vNext line 558 - p.Elements().Count()" (#185) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi Eric Thanks for the great library. I just discovered OpenXmlPowerTools recently and am using it to replace my old RTF based token replacement with DOCX to really save on those storage costs! Anyway, while working with some multi-line address data, delimited by '\n', I had a problem whereby not all of the
elements were being inserted. For example, say I have this text: 17 Shire Oak Road\nSaxlingham\nNR15 5TR I have 2 documents where I am attempting to insert this data formatted with new lines as an address. The first document, the token is replaced by the following which correctly contains a
inserted before the 2nd and 3rd elements: ```

17 Shire Oak Road
Saxlingham
NR15 5TR

``` The second document does not have the extra of the first and if you look you can see that it has not put the
before the second element. ```

17 Shire Oak Road Saxlingham
NR15 5TR

``` Am I right in saying that their is a bug here in that the test for p.Elements().Count() on line 558 should test for > 0 not > 1 ?? And that the only reason why it works in the first case is because of the extra guff which is present artificially increasing p.Elements().Count()? And that it should test only for a count of the element? Should it in fact show: (p.Elements(W.r).Count() > 0) This seems to work in my use case. Cheers Ben

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "binding directives in tables" (#184) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

I'm trying to use DocumentAssembler to generate documents based on xml files, and using repeat directive associated with table directive, i'm not being able to:

1. Use two expressions in one cell of the prototype row (like ./Price ./CurrencySymbol )
2. Use select content expression on table header. (like **Price** `<# <Content Select="./SaleItems/SaleItem[1]/@Currency"/> #>` ) - produces invalid document

Any help on this would be appreciated,

Best regards,
Manuel

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Merge styles with same name in DocumentBuilder" (#183) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
Solves #181.

Currently implemented with a compile-time feature flag, but this could easily be changed to an optional parameter passed to DocumentBuilder at run-time.

It is likely possible to clean up the section that maps style IDs in references and numberings so that it doesn't have to go through as many elements.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Reinstall NuGet packages in OpenXmlPowerToolsExamples projects" (#180) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
This commit completely removes all references to DocumentFormat.OpenXml
and System.IO.Packaging, some of which pointed to a local development
folder. This commit then reinstalls the DocumentFormat.OpenXml NuGet
package v2.7.2 from nuget.org.

For .NET Framework 4.5 and earlier, DocumentFormat.OpenXml no longer
uses System.IO.Packaging. For .NET Framework 4.6.1 and later,
DocumentFormat.OpenXml has a dependency on System.IO.Packaging, which
will get pulled from NuGet as required.
